Journal Story:
I retired the end of 2017 and enjoy travel, hiking, gardening, scuba diving, and snorkeling.Â  I consider myself to be a fairly physically active person, but am overweight (working at that).Â  I did my 1st attempt at a thru-hike of the AT in 2014 and hiked 554 miles north from Springer, having to take a month off before going through the Smokies due to a high left Achilles injury.Â  On my 2nd attempt (in 2018) that left Achilles continued to bother me and I never was able to get comfortable/ "get my trail legs"/ increase my daily mileage.Â  In 2018, I hiked about 1/3 of the way through the Smokies and turned around and hiked back to Fontana Dam and called it quits (hiked total of about 200 miles that year).Â  After that my left Achilles tendonitis/ bursitis persisted, flaring up on and off until late April, 2019 when a stool I was standing on at home flipped out from under me, I fell, and I ruptured my left Achilles tendon.Â  I underwent surgical repair on 5/30/19 and was placed in a splint and now am non-weight bearing on that leg/ foot.
Picture is from 6/4/19 - surgical dressing and splint.
So --- here I go again.Â  Still have that "white blaze fever".Â  Preliminary plan is to start a 3rd attempt at an AT thru-hike early in 2021.Â  A lot of variables to consider between now and then - 1st will be my recovery from my Achilles surgery.Â  More to follow.

I went to see my orthopedist for my 1st post-op follow-up visit 2 days ago.Â  He removed my splint and surgical dressing, then removed about 18-20 skin staples from a 7-8â€ long J shaped incision down my lower Achilles area and J hooked behind my left heel (incision looked clean and fairly well healed before he put cast on - that was nice to see, although I didnâ€™t expect that long an incision). Then 9 steri-strips placed across incision, lower leg/ ankle/ foot wrapped in â€œfeltâ€, and fiberglass cast put on.Â  Picture is of my new cast.
My orthopedist said he placed 4 â€œabsorbableâ€, non metallic screws thru my Achilles and into my calcaneous (heel) to hold the Achilles in place. Â He wants me non-weight bearing on my left foot/ leg for another month until I follow-up w/ him againÂ on Tuesday, 7/16.  
Then supposed to be in a "boot" for a month, then physical therapy.Â  My orthopedist says he thinks I should be able to eventually get back to long distance hiking.Â  More to follow.

When I started my AT hike in 2014, I weighed about 220# (see photo).Â  By the end of my hike that year (about 550 miles), I had lost about 30# and weighed about 190# (see my "about" photo).Â  I think at that time I felt like I was in my best physical shape in 30+ years.Â  
In 2018 when I started my AT hike I weighed 240#.Â  After hiking 200 miles, I had lost about 20#, but still weighed 220#.Â  Since then, partly due to activity limitations from my chronic left Achilles tendinopathy and partly due to poor dietary choices, I have gained 10# and now am struggling to not go above 230#.Â  Last year I started in worse physical shape and never felt like I got my trail legs.
I know better.Â  If my left leg/ Achilles cooperates and heals well, I will do better.Â  As soon as I get this cast off, I plan on doing everything I am told to do by my orthopedist and by physical therapy to get in shape for long distance hiking and a generally more active and healthy lifestyle.Â  
More to follow.

Cast was removed from my left lower leg last Tuesday, 7/16/19.Â  Sent home wearing a "walking boot" for at least 3 more weeks, but have started physical therapy.Â  I am full weight bearing on my left leg now, just supposed to wear the walking boot, except when I shower or sleep, to protect the Achilles tendon repair and allow time for it to heal.
Started physical therapy the day after the cast was removed and going twice/week - 2 visits so far, 3rd is tomorrow.Â  Doing home exercise regimen for 1-1/2 hrs twice/day.Â  Seems to be coming along slowly.Â  Trying to be religious about doing the home exercises.Â  Having a little pain/tenderness at my inner posterior heel area - hope it is just the surgery healing and that it resolves soon.Â  
I see the orthopedist again 2 weeks from today.Â  Hopefully I can get permission to ditch the walking boot and start walking/hiking.
More to follow

It has been almost 6 months since I last posted to my journal.Â  I finished my physical therapy the end of August, then started walking more.Â  I last saw my orthopedist, Dr. John DiPreta, on 12/10/19 (just over 6 months following my left Achilles tendon repair) and was given the "all clear" w/ no activity restrictions.Â  I can't explain how wonderful it is to walk w/out pain any more.Â Â  My thanks to Dr. DiPreta.
We (my wife and I) finished up 2019 celebrating the holidays visiting our 3 sons and their families.Â  Thanksgiving week was spent in Atlanta w/ our oldest son, his wife, and our 2 younger grandsons (ages 5 and 3).Â  Christmas week was spent in southern LA/ Redondo Beach w/ our middle son, his wife, and our 2 older granddaughters (ages 11 and 8) and older grandson (age 6).Â  Finally, for New Years/ Hanukkah week we were in Pittsburgh w/ our youngest son, his wife, and our youngest granddaughter (age 17 months).Â  We travel to see all our grandchildren several times each year and our sons and their wives invite us to stay in their homes.Â  We are truly fortunate and blessed to have such close relationships with them.
Throughout the holidays I considered what goals/resolutions I should set for myself for 2020.Â  I wanted to keep them simple.
#1- I had seen a post/ challenge on the internet suggesting running or walking 2020 miles in 2020 - so that is my #1 goal.Â  2020 miles is just over 5.5 miles/ day.Â  That seems not only doable, but appropriate w/ my planned 2021 AT thru hike attempt.Â  Unfortunately, I got off to a little bit of a late start.Â  I came home from Pittsburgh on New Year's Day w/ a bad cold and am just getting over it now.Â  So I started on this goal today with a 9 mile walk along our local Mohawk-Hudson Bike Hike Trail.Â  I am able to walk to this trail from my home (no drive needed) and as can be seen from the photo I can walk long distances on it.Â  I hope to add hikes in the high peaks in the Adirondacks, including some overnighters, in the spring, summer, and fall - those will require about a 2 hour drive.
#2- Like so many others, my 2nd goal is weight loss.Â  I am 65 years old, 5'11" tall (I think I was 6' when I was younger), and weigh 233#.Â  Like I said in a previous post, when I hiked in 2014, I started my hike at 220# and after hiking some 550+ miles my weight had dropped to 190# and I felt great.Â  When I hiked in 2018, I started my hike at about 240# and after hiking 200 miles my weight dropped to 220#, but I never felt I got my "trail legs".Â  My goal for this year then is lose some 20+# and get my weight down to 210#.Â  I am hoping that in the process of working on goal #1 that goal #2 happens simultaneously w/out much additional effort (other than dietary "moderation"). 
Happy New Year to all.
Life is GOOD!!!
#1-Cumulative 2020 miles - 9
#2-Weight - 233#

Since my last post I have continued to walk almost every day.
My average daily mileage has increased on a weekly basis as follows -
1-12/29/19-1/4/20 - 1 mile/day 
2-1/5/20-1/11/20 - 1.6 miles/day
3-1/12/20-1/18/20 - 4.2 miles/day
4-1/19/20-1/25/20 - 6.5 miles/day
5-1/26/20-2/1/20 - 8.7 miles/day.
There are a few hills where I am walking, but it is mostly level ground.Â  I hope to continue increasing daily average distance walked to the 10-13 mile range at a average speed of 3.2-3.4 mph.Â  I live in the Capital Region of NY and when the weather improves in the late spring I plan on hitting the high peaks area in the Adirondacks a couple days each week.Â  
This is far more prep work-out than I did before my attempted thru-hikes in 2014 and 2018, a major benefit of retirement and "free time".Â  
LIFE IS GOOD!!!
#1-Cumulative 2020 miles - 151
#2-Weight - 230#

Amazing and trying times we are all living through.Â  I hope all are healthy and doing what they need to in order to stay well.
My thoughts go out to the Class of 2020 - both those still hiking and those who have postponed or suspended their hike.
And for my fellow Class of 2021, I fear that our class will perhaps grow excessively large w/ those who reschedule their plans/ dreams to next year.Â  Only time will tell.
As for myself, I continue to try to walk regularly, although that has decreased somewhat in the last couple weeks for a variety of reasons (mostly because of a 2 week vacation on the water limiting my ability to walk, but made up for w/ lots of swimming and snorkeling).Â  So here are my numbers.
Average daily mileage -
6-2/2/20-2/8/20 - 9.5 miles/day
7-2/9/20-2/15/20 - 7.8 miles/day
8-2/16/20-2/22/20 - 7.2 miles/day
9-2/23/20-2/29/20 - 5 miles/day
10-3/1/20-3/7/20 - 0.7 mile/day
11-3/8/20-3/14/20 - 5 miles/day
My total miles walked for the 1st 79 days of 2020 is 423 miles, an average of 5.35 miles/day.
Please take care of yourselves.
LIFE IS GOOD!!!
#1-Cumulative 2020 miles - 423
#2-Weight - 226#

It has been a long 2 months since my last entry in this journal.Â  Living in NY State has been surreal.Â  NYS has had 352,845 confirmed Covid-19 cases and 28,558 Covid related deaths thru 5/19.Â  Although I live in Upstate NY where the outbreak has been nowheres as bad as in the downstate/ New York City area, the state as a whole has been under a stay at home order for 2 months now.Â  This week much of Upstate NY is beginning a phased reopening based on meeting certain "metrics".Â  Downstate is still closed.Â  Most of us are practicing social distancing and wearing masks when in public places/ within 6 feet of others.Â  Being a "senior citizen" (albeit a healthy one), I continue to limit my exposure as much as possible.Â  
All of that being said, I do live close to the Mohawk-Hudson Bike-Hike Trail and several nature preserves - within walking distance from my house so I don't even need to get in my car to use them.Â  These trails are rarely crowded enough to necessitate the wearing of a mask.Â  I continue to walk on them several times/week and have maintained my goal of averaging 5.5 miles/day.Â  Some days I work outside in my garden and yard and don't go out for a walk, some days weather is less cooperative, other days I take 3-6 hr walks.Â  Yesterday I did 15.6 miles.Â  Here are my numbers since my last post-
Average daily mileage -
12-3/15/20-3/21/20 - 5 miles/day
13-3/22/20-3/28/20 - 9.2 miles/day
14-3/29/20-4/4/20 - 1.9 miles/day
15-4/5/20-4/11/20 - 6.4 miles/day
16-4/12/20-4/18/20 - 4.9 miles/day
17-4/19/20-4/25/20 - 6.9 miles/day
18-4/26/20-5/2/20 - 4.3 miles/day
19-5/3/20-5/9/20 - 6.4 miles/day
20-5/10/20-5/16/20 - 6.2 miles/day
My total miles walked for the 1st 140 days of 2020 is 775.6, an average of 5.54 miles/day.Â  Most of these miles are over relatively flat terrain, so I will need to step up my game if I hope to be in shape for the trail next year.Â  In the next couple months I hope to start hiking the high peaks in the Adirondacks in Upstate NY (2 hrs drive north for me) and do some overnighters w/ full pack.Â  For those not familiar w/ the Adirondacks, there are 46 peaks of 4000+ ft elevation.Â  I would like to complete all 46 this spring/summer/fall.Â  
Despite all the anxiety and craziness of this Covid pandemic, LIFE IS GOOD!!!
#1-Cumulative 2020 miles - 775.6
#2-Weight - 224#
Please continue to take care of yourselves and stay well.Â  And good luck to the class of 2020 - hope you can get back out on your hike.

The last 3 months since my last post have seen some dramatic changes.Â  The Covid outbreak has moved thru much of the rest of the country and NY State is now doing well.Â  In fact, if I travel to any of 33 other states, Puerto Rico, or the US Virgin Islands and stay for 24 hours or more, I am required to quarantine for 14 days on my return home to NY.Â  Colleges in the area have accepted students back for in person classes.Â  Students attending them from any of the quarantine list states are being quarantined in their dorms for 14 days before being allowed to join in any activities.Â  
Our economy is opening up - all regions of New York have entered Phase 4 of reopening. Bowling alleys were able to reopen on 8/17, Gyms and fitness centers are reopening on Monday, 8/24.Â  Indoor shopping malls, movie theaters, and casinos remain closed.Â  But businesses are struggling still.Â  Many won't survive.
We (my wife and I) continue to socially isolate and wear masks when we go out.Â  We rarely go out other than for groceries except for my walks and in our yard.Â  My plans to start hiking the high peaks in the Adirondacks in Upstate NY have been delayed for various reasons - I hope to do some hiking there in the fall.I have generally continued my walking.Â  Here are my numbers since my last post-
Average daily mileage -
21-5/17/20-5/23/20 - 4.7 miles/day
22-5/24/20-5/30/20 - 2.7 miles/day
23-5/31/20-6/6/20 - 8.8 miles/day
24-6/7/20-6/13/20 - 3.9 miles/day
25-6/14/20-6/20/20 - 4.2 miles/day
26-6/21/20-6/27/20 - 6.7 miles/day
27-6/28/20-7/4/20 - 6.9 miles/day
28-7/5/20-7/11/20 - 7.8 miles/day
29-7/12/20-7/18/20 - 7.5 miles/day
30-7/19/20-7/25/20 - 6.5 miles/day
31-7/26/20-8/1/20 - 9.3 miles/day
32-8/2/20-8/8/20 - 4.5 miles/day
33-8/9/20-8/15/20 - 4.8 miles/day
34-8/16/20-8/21/20 - 2.7 miles/day
My total miles walked for the 1st 234 days of 2020 is 1317.5, an average of 5.63 miles/day.Â  I need to average 5.52 to walk my 2020 miles in 2020 (my goal), so I am on track to meet that goal.Â  
And my weight is down to 210#.
Now my change of plans.Â  We have 7 grandchildren now - 3 (ages 11, 9, and 7) in the southern LA are in California; 2 (soon to be ages 6 and 4) in Atlanta, Georgia; and 2 (ages 2 and almost 3 months) in Pittsburgh, PA.Â  Since our 1st grandchild was born we have traveled to see all of our grandchildren at least 4 times/year.Â  That stopped w/ Covid except for 1 trip (500 mile/8 hr drive) to Pittsburgh about 5-6 weeks ago to see our newest grandson (born on 6/10/20).Â  We (my wife and I) are in withdrawal and "need" to see our grandchildren.Â  To hike the AT in 2021 would mean delaying most visits w/ our grandchildren until the last 4 months of 2021.Â  After our isolation this year, I have made the decision to delay my AT hike until 2022.Â  I have edited my "about" page to reflect these changes and moved my start date to 2/15/22.
Again, please continue to take care of yourselves and stay well. Good luck to the class of 2020 - I am glad the trail reopened for you and hope you succeed in reaching your goal. Good luck to the class of 2021.Â  I will continue to follow your journals, blogs, and vlogs.

Goodby to 2020, but 2021 has started ominously.
Covid in the US is still raging w/ new cases, hospitalizations and deaths all at record levels.Â  The vaccine gives us hope, although the roll out so far has been less than optimal.Â  I remain optimistic that will improve over the next month, that our government agencies and the health care industry (our public health care system, hospitals, private health care providers, the pharmaceutical industry, and pharmacies) will become increasingly efficient and proficient at distributing and administering the vaccine.Â  In the meantime we (my wife and I) continue to physically distance ourselves and take all possible precautions.Â  This certainly has been made easier by us both being retired.Â  We do miss traveling to see our sons, their wives, and our grandchildren.Â  Hopefully that will change by this summer.
The events in Washington and the attack on our Capitol last week were sad and overwhelming.Â  I watched fixed to the tv, much as I recall watching during what transpired on 9-11.Â  I hope our country can get through the next 10 days peacefully.Â  After 9-11 our country seemed to come together, showing incredible strength and resilience against a common external enemy/ threat. This past week's threat was domestic and seems much harder to fight. There were most certainly extremists involved and who are still plotting against our democracy and our rules of law. There were certainly others involved that simply had opposing opinions to those of the "winning side" and got caught up in the "moment". Should they all be treated the same???
Our country needs to heal - how do we do that???
As for myself, I missed my goal of hiking 2020 miles in 2020.Â  I didn't do bad though, averaging 5.1 miles/day for the entire year - between 1850 and 1900 miles total.Â  I am setting my goal for 2021 at 6 miles/ day (2190 miles for the year), but trying a different method to get there.Â  I have been listening to (binging on) the Mighty Blue podcasts while walking 4-6 hrs most days, usually listening to 2-4 podcasts on each walk.Â  Mighty Blue describes in his book of his thru-hike in 2014 (coincidentally the same year as my 1st attempt) how he figured how many miles/day he needed to average to finish the trail, then tried to "bank" surplus miles and only take a zero when he had enough miles in the bank.Â  That is my plan this year to try to stay on schedule to reach my goal. On a more general note, the 2021 hiking season has begun and I look forward to reading and watching this year's hiker's blogs and vlogs.Â  Good luck to the Class of 2021.Â  Your hiking experiences may be different w/ shelters closed and town visits likely still strained at times w/ Covid still raging.Â  But while hiking the trail, seeing the magnificent vistas and scenery, sharing your daily lives w/ the AT tramily, I am sure you will be making memories that will last a lifetime.Â  Again, please continue to take care of yourselves and stay well.

Quick update today.Â  I am trying to follow my plan and have been doing fairly well at it so far in 2021.Â  Upstate NY winter weather can be tough, but it will hopefully prepare me for an early start next year.Â  I have different combinations of layered clothing and various head and neck gear (buffs, balaclava, fleece or wool hats) I resort to depending on temperature and weather conditions and generally can stay very comfortable down to 10-15 degrees. Today's 9 mile walk was in a snow squall that dumped about 1" snow during 1 hr of the walk.Â  I took this selfie and look a little "frosty", but felt very comfortable and thought it was 1 of my more enjoyable walks - everything looked so clean and fresh.Â  So far for the 1st 21 days of 2021 I am averaging 8.3 mils/ day, giving me about 48 miles "in the bank".Â  Again, my goal for 2021 is 6 miles/day for the whole year.Â  6 miles/day x 365 days = 2190 miles, or about the length of the AT. 
I am starting to enjoy some of the early 2021 AT hiking blogs and vlogs.Â  One of the more difficult hikes I have seen is by Greenleaf and Apple Pie who are SOBO (apparently they left Katahdin on 12/7/20) and are posting brief videos on Youtube - take a look.

It has been a LONG TIME since my last post.Â  I have continued my walks and am averaging just barely under 6 miles/day for 2022 so far (having walked 1546.5 miles in the 1st 258 days of the year).
My start date for my AT NOBO is now set for Wednesday, 2/9/2022.Â  I have reservations at The Lodge at Amicalola Falls for the nights of 2/7 and 2/8/22, then will start up the approach trail on 2/9/22 (146 days from today).

I hope my plans do better for my AT hike than the JMT hike I had planned w/ my middle son earlier this month.Â  After repeated attempts to get a permit thru the JMT lottery system w/ both my son and I applying, I finally got a permit for the 2 of us to start 9/23/21 from Happy Isles in Yosemite to hike SOBO to Mt Whitney.Â  I was aware that early winter weather could be a factor and after multiple attempts was able to get the permit changed to a start date of 9/11/21 from Lyell Canyon in Yosemite.Â  I had my flight to LAX booked for 9/8/21, we had reserved a 1 way car rental from LA to Mammoth Lakes for 9/10, had a room reserved at the Mammoth Mountain Inn for the night of 9/10, then YARTS bus tickets purchased (Mammoth Mountain Inn to Tuolumne Meadows Store - near the Lyell Canyon Trailhead) for the morning of 9/11. On the morning of Monday, 8/30 my son had mailed resupply buckets for us to Red's Meadow, Muir Trail Ranch, and to a hotel in Onion Valley.Â  Then that very evening (Monday, 8/30) we heard that they were closing all the national forests in California to redirect resources to fire fighting.Â  That meant that Donahue Pass (the Pass out of Yosemite) was closed as was most of the JMT south from there (only the trails in the National Parks would remain open).Â  As a result we had to cancel our planned JMT thru-hike, as did many others.Â  We understand and our prayers and thoughts go out to all the firefighters and those affected by the fires.Â  But I still feel down about missing this opportunity to hike the JMT, both because it would have been a great shake-down hike for my planned early start on the AT and because I am sure I would have loved hiking the JMT w/ my son.

On a brighter note, in prepping for the JMT hike, I had my gear all set out and it should be the same gear I start with on the AT.

It is hard to believe my start date is now just over 2 months away.Â  
I continue to walk and through the end of November I have walked a total of 2014 miles this year, averaging 6 miles/day for all of 2021 to date.
Since my last post here on 9/16/21, I have been listening to hiking podcasts (especially to "JESTER" Section Hiker) and became interested in the idea of switching from my mummy sleeping bag to a quilt.Â  I am an "active" sleeper and I often end up twisted up in my mummy bag by morning.Â  Anyways, Enlightened Equipment had a Black Friday sale w/ 20% off "stock" quilts and I couldn't resist.Â  I purchased the EE 0 degree Enigma Quilt.Â  It just arrived yesterday (my wife found the idea of a quilt amusing as she is a "Quilter" - obviously a quilt means something different to her than it does to me) and I tried it out w/ my Nemo Cosmo Insulated 25L Sleeping Pad.Â  It definitely feels warmer than my Marmot 15 degree Plasma Mummy Sleeping Bag and is 2-1/2 oz lighter.Â  In addition, I was planning on packing my Sea to Summit Reactor Thermolite Mummy Bag Liner (9 oz), but will not need that now.Â  Total weight savings of 11-1/2 oz w/ the switch.Â  Now my base weight for my backpack, tent, sleeping pad, and sleeping bag is an even 9#.Â  I know my sleeping pad is heavy, but I consider it to be my luxury item and my back and hips appreciate it every night.
I am looking forward to starting my hike and meeting other members of the Class of 2022 out on the trail.

Just under 3 weeks now.Â  I find myself thinking of starting my hike day and night.Â  I wake up early and imagine myself waking in my new quilt in my tent on the trail.Â  Pulling together my gear and supplies a little each day.
I finished 2021 walking/ hiking just short of my goal of averaging 6 miles/day.Â  I walked a total of 2137.5 miles in 2021, an average of just under 5.9 miles/day.Â  Some of my last miles were done in the southern NC Appalachian Mountains during the end of December.
Took a trip south w/my wife for the last 2 weeks of December- spent 2 weeks in timeshare in Sapphire Valley, NC (just 100 miles NE of Springer Mountain) and 1st 2 weeks of January - 3 nights in Asheville, 3 nights on Edisto Island, SC, then 1 week in Disneyworld.Â  On our drive from Sapphire Valley to Asheville, we drove into Franklin, NC and then up to Winding Stair Gap on Rte 64 and stopped at the parking area there (I was anxious to see those white blazes again).Â  Then we drove up the Blue Ridge Parkway (what a beautiful, scenic parkway) about 30 miles into Asheville.Â  
We took the Autotrain north from Sanford, FL to Lorton, VA on 1/14-1/15, then drove last 7-1/2 hrs home to Upstate, NY on 1/15.Â  Nice trip, but w/ driving >3000 miles and taking Autotrain 850 miles, I am ready to slow the travel down and start walking (although I still have to travel back down to Georgia to start my hike).
Thank you to those of you who have signed my guest book and offered your words of encouragement. 
See you on the trail.

I was ready to start my hike w/ my HOKA Speedgoat 4, but after several hikes locally in them including a 10 mile hike over 2 high peaks in the Adirondacks, I wasn't quite satisfied.Â  Sent for Altra Lone Peak 5's from REI (on sale now) and find them more comfortable, so plan on starting in them.Â  Did my 550 miles on AT in 2014 in Tevasphere sneakers and never had a blister, but can't find them anymore.Â  Did 200 miles in 2018 in Merrell Moab Vent sneakers and they were OK, so may switch to them later in the hike (I have a couple new pairs still).Â  I think I could possibly switch to the HOKA Speedgoat 4's later as well.Â  The Altra's feel extra comfortable w/ very wide forefoot/ toe box, so they will be what I start in.Â  
For camp shoes I will be using Body Glove sandals - just under 14 oz for the pair.
I will also be using Gaiters and will be carrying 2 pairs.Â  
1st - eVent Shortie Gaiters - 2-1/2 oz w/ bag (bag weighs 1/4 oz)2nd - Dirty Girl gaiters - 1 oz/ pair--- eVent for wet/ snowy/ muddy days.Â  Dirty Girl for dry days.

I think I have finalized my gear list and have a base weight (everything except food and water) of about 24#.Â  Not UL, but I am OK w/ that to start in the winter.Â  Might go up to 25# if I switch to my heavier rain gear (may do that thru the Smokies for added warmth).Still have to select and pack foodUsing LighterPack - https://lighterpack.com/r/uvrp...See you on the trail.

Drove to Pittsburgh w/ my wife and spent the weekend (2/3-2/7) w/ our youngest son, his wife, and our 2 youngest grandchildren (3-1/2 yo granddaughter and 1-1/2 yo grandson).Â  We had a great time visiting w/ them and our daughter-in-law's family.
On Monday, 2/7, we left their house in Pittsburgh at 8 AM and drove south to The Lodge at Amicalola Falls State Park in Georgia, arriving just after sunset about 6:30 PM - a long 10-1/2 hr drive.Â  Spent last night here at the Lodge w/ my wife and staying again tonight.Â  Today we spent time together, drove to Dahlonega, Woody Gap, and Neel Gap and then had a nice lunch in Dahlonega.Â  Tomorrow morning we will get a quick breakfast here, then check out of the Lodge and my wife will drop me off at the Springer Mountain Parking Lot.Â  I will start my hike south for 1 mile to Springer Mountain, sign the ledger there, retrace my steps north to the parking lot, then continue my journey north.Â  I did register at the Amicalola Falls Visitor Center this morning as hiker #116 (although I am starting tomorrow morning and a few hikers may have started today after I registered).I have made a few tweaks to my gear list.Â  The weather for the next 4 days is forecast (Blood Mountain forecast) to be sunny w/ daytime highs of 46-52 degrees.Â  My wife will be staying along my route in timeshares the next couple weeks and will be helping me slackpack a lot, so I am leaving my heavy winter gloves and microspikes with her.Â  I will also be carrying less food to start.Â  Looks like my starting carry weight will be a very respectable 29-30#.
And so my journey begins.

Was topping off charges on my electronics - Suunto Ambit 3 Watch, Battery bank, Neck speaker, Wireless airbuds, and Headlamp.Â  Everything was working before, Black Diamond Revolt Rechargeable Headlamp not working at all after.Â  I will try stopping at the Amicalola Falls Visitor Center on our way out in the morning and see if they have anything I can use.Â  Worse case is I will have to use my iPhone as a flashlight until I get to Mountain Crossings at mile 31.3.

My wife and I drove from the Lodge at Amicalola Falls State Park (where we had stayed Monday and Tuesday nights) to Springer Mountain Parking Lot this morning and I started my hike. Â I left the car at 9:45 AM and hiked 1 mile south to the top of Springer Mountain (the southern terminus of the Appalachian Trail) then hiked the mile back north to the parking lot where my wife was waiting, put on my backpack, and started my hike north about 11 AM. Â I hiked another 7.1 miles north on the trail to Hawk Mountain Shelter, arriving at 3:20 PM. Â I set up my tent, sleeping pad, and sleeping "quilt" and ate a light dinner. Â Now laying in my tent to keep warm.Weather was sunny today w/ high about 50. Â Should get down to 25-30 tonight, then sunny w/ high tomorrow about 53. Â Nice hiking weather, but cold at night. Â 5 other hikers sleeping in shelter here and 2 others in tents. Â Some others may arrive still, but almost everyone has eaten and gotten into their sleeping bags to keep warm.
28,314 steps today.
1 step at a timeğŸ˜Š

Last night 2 more hikers came in later, so there were 5 of us in tents + 5 in the shelter. Â 
Woke up about 6 AM today after going to sleep about 9 last night - seemed to sleep 1-2 hrs, then change position to get comfortable on 3-4" thick inflatable, insulated sleeping pad. Â This hike using 0 degree Quilt w/ sewn/ closed footbox, but no down or material beneath me from knees up. Â So when I turn over at night I have to tuck quilt under my sides to stay warm - got down to 25-30 last night.I got up as it got light at 7 AM (before sunrise), deflated and rolled up my sleeping pad, stuffed my quilt in its stuff sack, broke down and packed up my tent, made and ate oatmeal for breakfast, and packed up my backpack. Â I did not end up starting my hike until 9:15 AM. Â  Hopefully I will get more efficient.My original plan was to hike 12.4 miles to Woody Gap/ GA 60 and have my wife pick me up, sleep at the Comfort Inn in Dahlonega w/ her tonight, then have her drive me back to Woody Gap tomorrow morning.Well, 2.4 miles into today's hike I hit Sassafras Mountain - a steep 800 ft climb over 1 mile. Â That kicked my butt and after hiking a total of 7.6 miles (w/ a few more smaller ups and downs as weIl) arrived at Gooch Mountain Shelter (mile marker 15.7) at 4:30 PM - so I only averaged about 1 mph today. Â Woody Gap is another 4.8 miles - plan now is to hike that in the morning and have my wife pick me up about 12.After arriving at Gooch Mountain Shelter, I set up my tent, fixed a Mountain House pork sweet and sour dinner (just add boiling water) and ate it, blew up my sleeping pad (has built in foot pump), set up quilt, and laid out gear in tent. Â Now lying in quilt - not as cold tonight (supposed to get down to about 34 here). Â There are 8 other hikers here in tents and hammocks (including the 5 that slept at the shelter last night). There are 2 hikers staying in the shelter. Â The hikers who are here who were at the shelter last night all took about the same time as I did, so I don't feel so bad. Â It will get better.ğŸ˜ŠMy health app on my iPhone says 69 flights climbed yesterday,Â 97 flights climbed today.

Got up at 6 AM this morning. Â Only got down to about 35 last night.
Used the privy, broke down camp and packed everything into my backpack, then had breakfast essentials (2 envelopes + powdered milk + water), then filtered some water to fill my water bottles. Â I left the shelter at 7:50 AM - 1st one out and on the trail. Â Hope to get that camp breakdown/ packing down to 1 hr eventually.Had relatively easy hike, starting at 2766 ft elevation, hiking over 4 200-300 climbs and drops w/ maximum elevation of 3212 ft (picture above from there). Â Did what we call a nero (near zero) to Woody Gap/ GA 60 at mile 20.5, only 4.8 miles for today. Â My wife was at Woody Gap to pick me up - I had told her 11:15 AM, she actually arrived at 11:05, and I was there at 11:10. Â So 4.8 miles in 3 hrs, 20 min or just under 1.5 mph today.Now at the Comfort Inn in Dahlonega. Â My wife was here last 2 nights alone. Â When I got here I took long hot shower, ate a little. Â Now relaxing.Â Â Plan to go out to dinner w/ my wife and sleep here tonight. Â Will wake up about 6:30 tomorrow morning and go down to lobby and get quick breakfast, then wake my wife about 7, drive back to Woody Gap and start hiking from there about 8 AM. Â I will be slackpacking - no tent, sleeping pad, quilt, extra clothes, cookset, food bag, electronics (except will carry headlamp). Â Calculating worn weight + hiking poles just under 6#, carried weight w/ water and lunch/ snacks about 12# - better than normal carried weight of 30-32#. Â Plan on hiking from Woody Gap (3202 ft elevation) to Neel Gap, 10.8 miles over 2 big mountains. Â 1st mountain is Big Cedar Mountain (3737 ft elevation), 2nd is Blood Mountain (4459 ft elevation) then down to Neel Gap/ US 19 at 3125 ft where my wife will pick me up again.

My wifeÂ dropped me off at Hogpen Gap and I started hiking north at 10:45 AM today - later start because I was only planning a short 4.6 mile hike, then 9.7 miles tomorrow to Unicoi Gap where My wife will pick me up (hopefully I will be there by 4 PM). Â It was 28 and blustery w/ a 10-20 mph wind to start. Â Before I left the car, I had on my thin hooded LLBean hoodie, over that my 32 degree base layer, and over that my OR rain jacket to cut the wind. Â I put on a buff over my head and neck, then the hood of my hoodie, then a heavy fleece hat. Â And I wore my Spyder polyester gloves. Â 
I made fairly good time hiking over 4 small to medium peaks - the 1st 2 each about 200', the 2nd 2 each about 400'. Â No open views to take pix, although lots of views thru the mostly naked trees. Â Got to Low Gap Shelter about 1:20 PM and thought about eating lunch and hiking another 2 hrs/ 3-4 miles to a campsite and set up my tent, but combination of shelter, picnic table, water source, privy, and bear cables to hang my food convinced me to stay. Â Not a lot of flat ground here to set up my tent, so staying in the shelter tonight. Â That should also make it quicker to pack in the morning.
I visited w/ some other thru-hikers when I got to the shelter. Â The 4 who were at the 1st 2 shelters were here - trail names Artisan, Flex, Rocky, and Zero (Zero is actually only hiking for a couple weeks) - they set up tents and a hammock nearby. Â Thru-hiker Guam is staying in the shelter as well tonight. Â I think 3 other thru-hikers are also here setting up tents or hammocks. Â And section hiker Nap is staying in a tent.
Temp tonight is supposed to drop to 28, but tomorrow is supposed to be sunny w/ a high of 48 and only a 5 mph wind. Â Sun is going down now and temp drops as it does. Â Glad I have 0 degree quilt + down hoodie + down booties.

Moved w/ my wife to a new timeshare today. 
Ready to get back to hiking tomorrow.Â  Plan is to hike from Unicoi Gap to Dicks Creek Gap over next 2 days.Â  Tomorrow is forecast to be sunny w/ a high of 45 and minimal wind.Â  Tomorrow night partly cloudy w/ a low around 34.Â  Then Monday, cloudy w/ a 30% chance of showers (mainly after 3 PM) and with a high near 51.

We drove from timeshare back to Unicoi Gap (about 1 hr drive) and My wife dropped me off/ I started hiking about 9:20 AM. Â I hadn't gone more than 30 seconds and I realized I had left my knee braces (strap braces I wear just below my kneecaps) in the car. Â Fortunately I had cell service and was able to call my wife - she was able to turn around before she had gone a mile and returned to Unicoi Gap. Â I put on my braces, said my goodby again, and started hiking at 9:30. Â The trail immediately started up a steep mountain w/ a 1050 ft ascent. Â I made fairly good time going up this one to near top of Rocky Mountain (side trail to peak I skipped). Â About 10:30 I reached viewpoint at top of 1st ascent (see photo). Â Then had 900 ft descent to Indian Grave Gap where the AT crosses a Forest Service Rd w/ parking. Â Left Indian Grave Gap about 11:20 AM and started longer 1300+ ascent to top of Tray Mountain. Â Reached that about 1:05 PM. Â Continued to hike along a ridge line w/ a few smaller 200-300 ft ups and downs until I reached Sassafras Gap at 4:45 PM - a total of 10.3 miles for the day. Â Walked .2 miles, 125 ft down a side trail to get water from a spring (yes, I filter all my water), then walked back up to main trail to set up my camp/ tent for the night.Â Â Had Carnation Essentials (instant breakfast) for dinner - too tired to cook. Â Went to sleep about 7:30 PM. Â Saw 9 dayhikers hiking south thru the day. Â There were 2 Thru-Hiker's that went north past me about 6 PM as I was hanging my bear/ food bag. Â It was a beautiful day for hiking - sunny w/ a high of 45-50 and minimal wind.36,850 steps today.1 step at a timeğŸ˜Š

Today, 2/21 - I awoke early, about 5:30 AM but waited until 6 to get out of my quilt. Â Temperature was about 35. Â I deflated my sleeping pad and rolled it up, stuffed my quilt in its stuff sack, broke down and packed up my tent. Â I packed up my backpack, fixed breakfast (Carnation Essentials again) and sat on a log and drank it. Â Watched sunrise about 7:15 AM. Â Started hiking about 7:45 AM and ran into few other Thru-Hikers about 1-1/2 hrs later. Â Then about 10:30 AM met this dayhiker walking her goat (see photo), heading south. Â Finally about 12:15 PM made it to Dicks Creek Gap where I found Fresh Ground had set up his "Leapfrog Cafe" and was cooking burritos and beef stew, had fresh fruits, cookies and other sweets, and cold drinks (soda and Gator Aid) - all free for hikers. Â Fresh Ground travels up the AT w/ his van for about 4 moths doing this "trail magic" for Thru-Hikers - he is able to do it from donations he receives thru a Go Fund Me.
I had arranged for my wife to pick me up at Dicks Creek Gap at 12:30 PM, so I had a few minutes to visit w/ the other Thru-Hikers and had a Gator Aid and a can of coke. Â My wife then arrived as planned, we drove to Clayton, GA and had a nice lunch at a restaurant, then drove back to our timeshare.20,548 steps today.1 step at a timeğŸ˜Š
